title: guille1976
author: guille1976
content: Hi everybodyI have had a antminer 86t plugged in for a couple of days working fine , then red light and error_soc_init ..... i have cleaned updated firmware etc ,this is my log could any body give me any advice? thanks2015-01-01 00:00:15 Open miner sn file /config/sn error2015-01-01 00:00:15 Miner compile time: Mon Dec 26 17:10:01 CST 2022 type: Antminer BHB42XXX sn :2015-01-01 00:00:16 comments.author: ZeusBtc.com
comments.body: Quote from: guille1976 on December 11, 2023, 06:48:52 PM2023-11-30 13:42:30 Chain[0]: find 82 asic, times 02023-11-30 13:42:32 Chain[0]: find 82 asic, times 12023-11-30 13:42:34 Chain[0]: find 81 asic, times 22023-11-30 13:42:34 Chain 0 only find 81 asic, will power off hash board 0Please check whether the cable is connected properly. If there is no problem with the cable, use the test fixture to test the board.

comments.author: mikeywith
comments.body: Quote from: guille1976 on December 11, 2023, 06:48:52 PM2023-11-30 13:42:30 Chain[0]: find 82 asic, times 02023-11-30 13:42:32 Chain[0]: find 82 asic, times 12023-11-30 13:42:34 Chain[0]: find 81 asic, times 22023-11-30 13:42:34 Chain 0 only find 81 asic, will power off hash board 02023-11-30 13:42:36 Chain[1]: find 88 asic, times 02023-11-30 13:42:38 Chain[2]: find 88 asic, times 02023-11-30 13:42:38 ERROR_SOC_INIT: soc init failed!2023-11-30 13:42:38 stop_mining: soc init failed!2023-11-30 13:42:38 uninit_temp_info2023-11-30 13:42:38 do not read temp anymore...2023-11-30 13:42:38 cancel thread2023-11-30 13:42:38 ****power off hashboard****This is the most important part of any Bitmain kernel log you read, you should always check the ASIC count status.Sadly, with all of these different varieties of the same miner mode, it became very difficult to remember the number of chips on each hashboard, but for your miner it seems like the number is 88 ASIC, if it finds less than that on any of the hashboards (called chain in the kernel log) the miner won't hash away.You can see that your chain 0 (probably the left with you facing the miner) managed to find only 81 ASICs, while 1 and 2 found 88, in the first attempt it found 82, it tried again to hopefully find 88 but it only found 81 the second time, this means, you most likely have an issue in that domain anywhere around chip 81-82-83-84, this will need some skills and knowledge to fix.So if it's still under warranty, file a warranty ticket, otherwise, just remove chain 0 from the miner and the miner would hash with 2/3 of it's hashrate.also to be sure that it's indeed a chip failure, you may switch 0 and 1 chains and check.If the warranty is done with, there are a few things you could try, you could try freezing the hashboard for 1-2 days (put it in a sealed plastic bag inside the freezer), I had some luck with this method, the other method would be the opposite, which is putting it in the oven or something, but I'd be careful doing so although some people reported success with it.so ya, it all boils down to the warranty, if it's still valid -- do not even attempt to switch hashboards as that will void the warranty.

comments.author: BitMaxz
comments.body: It seems there is issue on the first hashboard just like others pointed too.I have another suggestion As the above said it can void the warranty if you touch any hardware so focus on software-related issues and maybe we can fixed/bypass this issue and let the miner run normally.First, try to run the miner at low power mode you can find this under pool configuration this works sometimes.2nd if you want to bypass and want to keep the first hashboard try to boot this unit with Braiins OS and let it ignore the 1 ASIC chip.
